header.title: The Demon Lists - Compiled by Rev. Satrinah Nagash

central_thesis: This extensive compilation serves as a comprehensive, cross-cultural reference for identifying, understanding, and potentially interacting with demonic entities. It details their names, attributes, hierarchical positions, forms, and practical abilities, drawing from various magical and mythological traditions.

structure_content.summary: This section catalogs demonic entities whose names begin with 'A' or 'B'. Entries provide details on their rank (e.g., King, Duke, Marquis), number of legions, specific powers (e.g., prophecy, causing disease, teaching arts), typical appearances, and cultural origins (e.g., Arabic, Enochian, Babylonian, Persian, Hindu). It also lists numerous 'servitor' spirits and their associated higher demons and functions.

This section details demons whose names start with 'C', 'D', or 'E'. It includes powerful figures like Caym and Cimeries, servitor spirits, and various mythological demons (e.g., Cacus, Charun, Druj). Descriptions cover their roles in hell, unique abilities (e.g., understanding animal languages, discovering hidden treasures), and connections to specific cultures (e.g., Assyrian, Etruscan, Iranian).

This section covers demons from 'F' through 'H', featuring entities like Flauros, Furfur, and Gaap. It outlines their hierarchical positions, legions commanded, and magical functions, such as foretelling the future, inciting love/hatred, causing natural disturbances, and granting knowledge. Cultural references include Hungarian, Japanese, Sumerian, and Persian mythologies, along with Qabalistic attributions.

This section presents demons with names from 'I', 'J', and 'K'. It includes the powerful Ipos, mythological figures like Ifrits and Jinn, and various servitors. Descriptions highlight their abilities (e.g., imparting wit and courage, finding hidden treasures), forms, and cultural contexts (e.g., Arabic, Indonesian, Japanese, Eskimo), often noting their roles in various magical practices.

This section compiles demons from 'L' to 'M', featuring prominent entities such as Leonard, Leviathan, Lilith, Lucifer, and Mammon. It outlines their supreme ranks (e.g., Crown Princes of Hell, Grand Masters), specific domains (e.g., black magic, chaos, greed), legions, appearances, and deep mythological significance, including Qabalistic associations and grimoire-specific roles.

This section covers demons with names beginning with 'N', 'O', or 'P'. It includes high-ranking figures like Naberius, Orias, and Paimon, along with servitors and mythological entities (e.g., Namtar, Paigoels, Phoenix). Details encompass their abilities (e.g., restoring dignities, teaching astrology, influencing love), forms, and roles within the infernal hierarchy, often noting specific instructions for their evocation.

This section lists demons from 'Q' to 'S', featuring entities such as Raum, Ravana, and Satan. It describes their powers (e.g., destroying cities, causing love, ruling elements), appearances, and hierarchical positions (e.g., Count, Crown Prince). Cultural origins like Hindu, Japanese, and Persian mythologies are noted, alongside Qabalistic and grimoire-specific attributions and functions.

This section contains demons from 'T' to 'V', including major figures like Typhon, Uvall, and Valac, as well as various servitors. Descriptions detail their powers (e.g., transforming metals, causing disease, granting love), forms, and mythological contexts (e.g., Sumerian, Egyptian, Japanese). This section also highlights the destructive and transformative aspects of these entities.

This final section covers demons from 'X' to 'Z', including entities such as Xaphan, Yama, and Zagan. It describes their roles within infernal regions, powers (e.g., causing lies, changing substances, making fools wise), and cultural significance (e.g., Hindu, Chinese). The section concludes the list, offering a comprehensive overview of various demonic figures and their specific attributes.

key_concepts.definition: A spiritual entity, often malevolent or powerful, with specific attributes, powers, and hierarchical positions across various cultures and magical traditions. These entities can be kings, dukes, marquises, or lesser servitors.

A subordinate or lesser spirit, typically associated with and serving a higher-ranking demon (e.g., 'A servitor of Astaroth and Asmodeus'). They often embody specific concepts or perform discrete tasks.
Units of demons, numbering between 3 and 200, commanded by higher-ranking demonic entities (e.g., Kings, Dukes, Marquises). The size of a demon's legion often indicates its power and influence.

A structured system of command among demons, including titles such as King, Prince, Duke, Marquis, Earl, and President, along with specialized roles like 'Chief' or 'Ambassador'. This hierarchy dictates their authority and the scope of their powers.

Specific functions attributed to demons, ranging from foretelling past/present/future, teaching arts/sciences, causing or curing diseases, discovering hidden treasures, influencing emotions (love/hatred), to altering physical reality or granting familiars.

The act of summoning or calling upon these spirits for specific purposes. The text implies that success in these operations often depends on knowing the demon's true name, form, rank, and employing specific ritual elements like protective circles or timing.

Links made between certain demons and the Qabalistic Sephiroth (e.g., 'Evil chief of Hod,' 'Evil chief of Kether'), suggesting their role as qlippothic or inverted aspects of divine emanations within esoteric traditions.

key_concepts.term: Servitor Lords (Oriens, Paimon, Ariton, Amaymon, Astaroth, Asmodeus, Magoth, Kore, Beelzebub)
key_concepts.definition: Powerful demonic entities who preside over regions or command vast numbers of servitor spirits. Oriens, Paimon, Ariton, and Amaymon are specifically identified as the 'Evil Kings of the four quarters of the world'.

practical_system.description: The text functions as a technical reference manual for a grimoire-style operative magic system. It implicitly supports the summoning and command of demonic entities to achieve specific magical outcomes. The core mechanism relies on precise identification of the demon (name, rank, form, legions) and understanding its unique powers and domain. Success in operations is often contingent on adhering to specific conditions and utilizing appropriate magical tools and protective measures during evocation.
tools: Magick Ring: A protective device for the operator (e.g., required when evoking Astaroth or Beleth).
Magic Triangle: A containment or compelling device for demons (e.g., Furfur, Haures, Shax often require appearance 'within the triangle').
Hazel Wand: A directional or commanding implement (e.g., Beleth commanded with 'hazel wand...pointed to the southeast').
Sword/Lance/Scepter: Symbolically or actually wielded by demons, potentially represented by the magician (e.g., Andras carries a 'sharp bright sword', Abigor bears a 'lance, standard or scepter').
Pentacle: A magical design or object, sometimes serving as the form for a demon's appearance (e.g., Decarabia appears 'in the form of a star in a pentacle').
Talismans, Bottles, Magic Rings: Objects used to enclose or contain familiar spirits (e.g., Agathion can enclose itself in these).
rituals: Invocation/Evocation: Summoning demons to manifest or influence reality, often for specific requests (e.g., knowledge, material gain, causing/curing conditions).
Hierarchical Command: Directing demons based on their rank and relationship to superior entities (e.g., 'obedient to Lucifer,' 'subordinates are Buer, Gusoyn, and Botis').
Protective Measures: Employing specific safeguards like 'magick rings' or a 'triangle' for containment and safety during interaction, as demons can be 'dangerous' or 'will kill the unwary'.

Specific Timing: Performing evocations during designated periods (e.g., 'Amoymon can be invoked from 9am to Noon,' 'Counts of Hell may be evoked at all hours of the day, provided the evocation takes place in a wild, unfrequented spot').

Offerings and Homage: Presenting gifts or showing respect to powerful entities to gain their cooperation (e.g., 'Belial must have offering and gifts,' 'Beleth must be received courteously and with homage').

relevant_quotes.text: Welcome to the famous Demon List. I have compiled this list over many years, and have made some recent updates to it. New demons have been added within the last couple of months. This list contains names of demons from just about every culture. If you can't find it elsewhere, you will probably find it here.
Abaddon - (1) King of Demons. The Destroyer. Male. (2) Chief Demon of Locusts. (3) Chief of the demons of the seventh hierarchy.

Agares - (1) Duke. 31 Legions of Spirits. Could be also spelled Aguares, however, the amount of legions is different between the two. (2) Grand Duke of the eastern region of Hades. He is shown in the form of a benevolent lord mounted on a crocodile, carrying a hawk on his fist. The army he protects in battle is fortunate because he disperses their enemies, and puts new courage in the hearts of cowards who flee before superior numbers. He distributes place and power, titles and prelacies, teaches all languages, and has other equally remarkable powers. 31 legions.
Asmodeus - (1) Tempter of women to fornicate with men. Male. (2) Lust. (3) Superintendent of Casinos.

Paimon - (1) King. 200 Legions of Spirits. Bind any man subject to the magickian. (2) A great king, very obedient to Lucifer. He appears like a crowned man seated on a dromedary, preceded by all manner of musicians. He speaks with a roaring voice, teaches all arts, sciences and secrets, gives and confirms dignities, makes men subject to the will of the Magickian, provides good familiars. He is observed towards the north-west, and is of the Order of Dominions.

Satan - (1) One of the four Crown Princes of Hell. Ruler of the Southern quadrant. His element is fire, and rules justice and passion. (2) Leader of the Opposition. (2) From Hebrew, ShTN, an adversary. (4) Evil chief of Kether.

critical_analysis.relevance: This compilation is highly relevant for practitioners of ceremonial magic, grimoire traditions, demonolatry, and qlippothic magic, as well as scholars of occultism and comparative demonology. It consolidates a vast amount of information on diverse demonic entities, their specific attributes, and hierarchical positions, which is crucial for operative magical work. The inclusion of 'servitor' spirits points to a granular approach to magical operations, allowing for targeted requests. References to Qabalistic 'evil chiefs' connect the work to more advanced esoteric studies, providing a framework for understanding demonic forces within a broader mystical cosmology.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of experienced ceremonial magicians, grimoire practitioners, demonolators, and occult researchers. It also serves as a valuable resource for academics and students of Western Esotericism, comparative religion, and folklore interested in the detailed classification and characteristics of demonic entities across cultures and historical periods.
